content: How can I help you today?

Well, I’ve been having a really hard time sleeping lately. It’s like my mind just won’t stop racing at night. There’s a lot going on with work, and I’m seriously scared about losing my job. My partner suggested I come here, so… here I am.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like things have been heavy for you with work stress and difficulty sleeping. Your partner's suggestion to reach out here shows care for your well-being. How have these sleepless nights been affecting you?

Honestly, it’s been rough. I’m always tired and irritable during the day, which makes it even harder to focus at work. It’s like this cycle I can’t seem to break, and it just adds to the pressure I’m already feeling. I don’t know what to do about it.

That sounds overwhelming—the lack of sleep and the stress both feeding into each other and making everything harder. It’s understandable that you're feeling stuck in this cycle, given how much is weighing on you. What have you tried so far to manage this?

Not much, honestly. I’ve tried scrolling on my phone to distract myself until I feel tired, but it doesn’t really help. I kind of just lie there, going over all the things that could go wrong at work and what that would mean for my family. It’s exhausting.

It sounds like trying to distract yourself hasn’t given you the relief you were hoping for, while your worries and responsibilities keep circling in your mind. That exhaustion must make it even harder to face everything during the day. What do you think might help you start breaking out of this cycle?

I really don’t know. I mean, I guess if I could find a way to stop overthinking everything at night, that might help. But it feels impossible to just shut my brain off when I’m so worried about everything.

That feels like such a tough situation—the worry feels so strong that it keeps you trapped in overthinking, especially when you’re trying to rest. Finding a way to settle your mind seems important to you, even if it feels out of reach right now. What helps you feel a sense of calm or focus during the day, if anything?

Honestly, not much lately. I’ve tried watching TV or spending time with my kids, which helps for a little while, but the stress always comes creeping back. It’s hard to fully relax when everything feels so uncertain.

It sounds like moments with your kids or enjoying TV do give you a brief escape, though the stress seems to linger just underneath it all. Balancing everything must feel really tough, especially with the uncertainty at work. Is there anything else you'd like to talk about or explore together?

I guess I just don’t know how to stop feeling like everything is about to fall apart. It’s like I’m waiting for the other shoe to drop, and I don’t know how to handle that feeling. I want to be a good partner and a good parent, but I’m scared I’m going to fail them.

Thank you for sharing how deeply you're feeling this. It’s clear how much you care about your family and want to support them, even while facing so much fear and pressure inside yourself. That "waiting for the other shoe to drop" feeling must feel constant and draining. How do you think things might look if you were able to ease some of that fear—even just a little?

I guess if I could let go of some of this fear, maybe I’d sleep better and feel more present with my family. It would just take a huge weight off my shoulders, you know? But I can’t imagine how to even start doing that. It all seems so overwhelming.

It sounds like letting go of some of the fear could make a big difference—better sleep, more connection with your family, and relief from that heavy burden you've been carrying. Even though starting feels overwhelming, the fact that you’re thinking about what easing that fear could mean shows a lot of strength. Would you be open to exploring any small steps that might help ease that weight?

It sounds like letting go of some of the fear could make a big difference—better sleep, more connection with your family, and relief from that heavy burden you've been carrying. Even though starting feels overwhelming, the fact that you’re thinking about what easing that fear could mean shows a lot of strength. Would you be open to exploring any small steps that might help ease that weight?

Thank you for considering the idea of small steps—it’s a positive start, given how overwhelming everything feels right now. Sometimes focusing on just one manageable step can provide a little relief and momentum. What small actions do you think could be possible for you, even if they’re just a first step?

I’m not really sure. Maybe I could try writing things down to get them out of my head or something. Or even just taking a break from my phone before bed could help, but I don’t know if that would make a big difference. It’s hard to know where to start.

Those are great ideas—writing things down and stepping away from your phone before bed could both be small shifts that help calm your mind. Even trying one of them might be a way to start exploring what feels helpful. What do you think about giving one of those a try?

Those are good suggestions. Writing things down could help clear your mind a bit, and taking a break from your phone before bed might reduce some of that overstimulation before sleep. Starting small is okay—how would you feel about trying one of these ideas tonight?

It sounds like writing things down or taking a break from your phone could be a meaningful first step toward easing your stress before bed. Starting small feels manageable, especially when things feel heavy. How do you feel about choosing one to try and just seeing how it goes?
